message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a mechanical obstruction in the lower gastrointestinal tract, and failure to pass meconium further supports this. Among the options, submucosa and muscularis externa are the layers responsible for peristalsis and movement of contents through the gut, and an abnormality in these layers could result in obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient may have Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa in the colon, leading to functional obstruction and symptoms such as abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. The other options do not have a direct connection to Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms most likely indicate Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by an absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses of the colon. This absence can cause a functional obstruction and lead to symptoms such as abdominal distention, vomiting, and constipation. Therefore, the abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa best explains the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa layers of the large intestine. This leads to a functional obstruction of the colon and symptoms such as abdominal distention, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. The tight anal sphincter and explosive passage of air and feces on removal of the examining finger also support the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the lack of meconium passage, suggest that the baby has Hirschsprung disease. This disease affects the submucosa and muscularis externa layers of the colon. The tight anal sphincter and explosive passage of air and feces on removal of the examining finger are also consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms suggest a condition called Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa in the colon. This leads to a functional obstruction and ultimately abdominal distension and vomiting. The tight anal sphincter and explosive passage of air and feces on removal of the examining finger are indicative of an obstructed colon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a bowel obstruction and the absence of meconium suggests an intestinal atresia or stenosis, which is commonly caused by abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa. This can cause a blockage or narrowing in the intestine, leading to abdominal distension and vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by abnormal development of the submucosa and muscularis externa in the colon. This leads to a functional obstruction and symptoms such as abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium. The anal sphincter may also be tight due to lack of innervation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest bowel obstruction, and the absence of meconium indicates meconium ileus, which is commonly associated with cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is caused by abnormal development of submucosa and muscularis externa in the gastrointestinal and respiratory systems.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is a disorder of the submucosa and muscularis externa layers of the intestine. This results in functional obstruction and can cause abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium.
